messageBody:
When you construct a LoadTest, a ThreadedTest and its associated
ThreadBarrier are used by default, so there's no need to decorate the
LoadTest instance as a ThreadedTest. Here's an example suite() method
that adds two LoadTest instances to the suite, each with different load
testing parameters:

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();

Timer timer = new ConstantTimer(0);

int maxUsers = 1;
int iterations = 50;
long maxElapsedTime = 60000;

Test testCase1 = new ExampleTestCase("testFoo");
Test loadTest1 = new LoadTest(testCase1, maxUsers, iterations,
timer);
Test timedTest1 = new TimedTest(loadTest1, maxElapsedTime);

maxUsers = 10;
iterations = 100;
maxElapsedTime = 120000;

Test testCase2 = new ExampleTestCase("testBar");
Test loadTest2 = new LoadTest(testCase2, maxUsers, iterations,
timer);
Test timedTest2 = new TimedTest(loadTest2, maxElapsedTime);

suite.addTest(timedTest1);
suite.addTest(timedTest2);

return suite;
}

Mike
